Dear Mr. Scheuer:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on January 13-
January 21, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the
contract and Modified Settlement Agreement (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination
and assessment of all of the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
Six licensed foster home files were reviewed. Two out of six files
did not have a social worker interview or the children’s
interviews documented.
R 400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child's record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R 400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Four out of eight foster
care files did not have placement preparation completed within
7 days after placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 2017, RENEWAL 2018
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's
age, appropriate to the child's capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
4

(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R 400.12417
Eight foster care files were reviewed.
Two out of eight did not complete replacement preparation as
required.
Three out of eight files did not have contact the necessary
parties when a change of placement occurred.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 2017 AND RENEWAL 2018
One out of eight did not have provide the necessary information
to the caregiver outlined in R 400.12417.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child
in a foster home, then both of the following shall be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs that
remain to be met.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight did not
have a summary of care from the previous placement in the file.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(i) A statement from a parent or licensed medical
authority which indicates that immunizations are current or
contraindicated is sufficient documentation of
immunizations.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight did not
have documentation that the child was up to date on
5

immunizations or a statement from parent of licensed medical
authority.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight foster
care files did not provide the foster parent with the above
information upon placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 2017 AND RENEWAL 2018
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the permanency
goal for the child.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight foster
care files did not have an updated permanency plan. It was cut
and paste from last service plan.
REPEAT VIOLATION INTERIM 2017 AND RENEWAL 2018
6

R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and
parenting time that contains, at a minimum, all of the
following:
(a) A plan of visitation for each child in foster care
consistent with the child's service plans, as required by R
400.12419 and R 400.12420 to assure the safety and well
being of the child.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight files did
not follow the visitation plan identified in the service plan. The
foster child was placed in the foster home on 8/26/19 and a
parenting visit did not occur until 9/20/19. The second child did
not have weekly parenting time from 810/19-8/30/19 and from
9/7/19-9/20/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722.03 page 14-16 Placement exception request (PER) – Was
a PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
A placement must not be made if it will result in one of the following:
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight files did not have PER’s
completed for sibling splits.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 Page 11-13 Medical Passports
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight did not have medical passports
as required.
DHHS Policy FOM722-06I (Page 4) General Supervision Requirement
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did not have observation
of parenting time documented.
7

REPEAT VIOLATION RENEWAL 2018
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H page 15-16 TIMELY ENTRY OF CASEWORKER
CONTACTS
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Three out of eight files did not have timely entry

DHHS Policy 722-06B page 1-7 Family Team Meeting
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Four out of eight files did not have FTM’s
completed for placement, replacement, or service plans.
IV. Analyst Safety Concerns
No safety concerns reported.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas: R. 400.12324
Reevaluation.
8

VI. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation in the following areas:
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Corrective Action Plan was completed for renewal 2018.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MSA requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
